g.text: We performed two common garden experiments to investigate phenotypic variation in parasitic
. Our ‘species differences’ (SpD) experiment observed life history trait differences of five
species and six natural hybrids when grown on clover (
), which is often used as a
host in parasitic plant experiments because the parasite grows vigorously and has high survival [17].
This experiment includes multiple populations of three widespread and closely related species,
, and a single population of two more distinct taxa,
. Our ‘phenotypic plasticity’ (PP) experiment assessed the impact of eight hosts
), and growing without a host, on parasite
phenotype. These hosts were chosen to represent both typical hosts encountered in the wild, as well as
novel hosts, and a broad representation of phylogenetic diversity and functional groups (full details in
Table S1). Both common garden experiments took place in parallel in 2016. Wild-collected open-
seeds were contributed by plant recorders as part of the ‘Eye for Eyebrights’
(E4E) public engagement project and as such included a scattered geographic sample across Great
Britain (Table S2). Host seeds were sourced from commercial suppliers and from wild-collected
can be challenging due to low seed germination, variation in time to
establishment, the requirement of seed stratification, and high seedling mortality when transplanted
[17, 18]. Here, we develop cultivation protocols that combine winter germination cues that improve
germination and mimic nature, but also use highly standardised and replicated pot conditions that
and thus maximise survivorship. We planted a single
into 9cm plastic pots filled with Melcourt Sylvamix® Special growing media in December, with
